I see this as an opportunity for bipartisan cooperation, and I look forward to advancing solutions to close the skills gap during the next Congress.

If our aim is to train more skilled workers (as it 100% should be), we gain nothing by restricting their options for when, where, and how to access that training. 

We must encourage more employer-led innovation in the apprenticeship space to maximize workers' gains.

Almost two years ago, I spoke on the House Floor against eliminating these apprenticeships because doing so is extremely counterproductive. 

The business community knows the best way to fill their needs ‚Äî they should be in the driver's seat! 

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=LJzG9ZzQVAQ

The Trump administration had it right: they recognized that employers are in the best position to respond to the changing needs of our modern workforce. 

The current administration is operating under the assumption that the government knows best. 

I disagree.

Unfortunately, House Democrats and the Biden administration have opted for only a one-size-fits-all federal registered apprenticeship system that imposes more bureaucratic red tape and requirements on businesses versus a model that provides flexibility and options.

I was encouraged to see that, this week, @GovKemp and @TCSG announced the creation of 120 new apprenticeships to train workers in high-demand fields like healthcare, manufacturing, and construction.

https://gov.georgia.gov/press-releases/2022-11-15/governor-kemp-and-tcsg-announce-historic-apprenticeship-investment

On #NationalApprenticeshipWeek, it's important we recognize that a four-year degree isn't the only pathway to success. 

Apprenticeships give people a chance to earn while they learn and prepare them for in-demand jobs. The federal government should help, not hurt, these efforts!

So what lessons did we learn? 

1.Implement measures to require states to count ballots more quickly. 
2.Require voter identification when requesting mail-in ballots. 
3.Maintain updated and accurate voter rolls. 

Read more by clicking the link below! 

https://tenney.house.gov/sites/evo-subsites/tenney.house.gov/files/evo-media-document/eic-midterm-bulletin_final.pdf

The ugly? 

California. California's state law does not require the canvas of ballots to be complete until a FULL MONTH after the election. This causes undue delays that ultimately hamper the democratic process for no reason. We should have Election Day, not Election month.

It was just as bad in Nevada, which does not maintain updated voter rolls or require any ID to vote. After Nevada passed an all mail-in ballot law last year, it totally failed to provide the necessary personnel or technical expertise to implement it effectively.

The bad?

Broken tabulators, slow reporting, and unhurried counting plagued elections in Arizona and Nevada. Voters in Arizona faced unacceptably long wait times and the state's lack of voter ID requirements for mail-in ballots left open the possibility for ballot harvesting.

In Georgia, a record 2.5 million early voters turned out for the midterms. Georgia's election integrity law was not "Jim Crow 2.0" as Joe Biden disgustingly claimed. In fact, early in-person voting was expanded along with voting hours. The bill BOOSTED turnout.

The good? 

On Election Night, the real winners were the voters of Florida and Georgia! Both states experienced well-run elections b/c of recently passed election integrity measures that strengthened mail-in balloting, expanded voting access, and required prompt ballot counting.

üö®The 2022 Midterms demonstrated the best and the worst of election administration!
